text: You're invited to the first stop on the BlueOval Battery Park Michigan Recruiting Roadshow this summer!   Join us to explore the latest developments at one of the most exciting projects in the country. You'll have the opportunity to meet our team, gain insights into upcoming career opportunities, and see how we're building more than just a plant - we're building a community.  This is your chance to learn how to join us to create a better tomorrow. We look forward to meeting you!   Our first stop will be in: Battle Creek, Michigan on Wednesday, May 21 from 4 p.m. - 8 p.m.  Register now: http://spr.ly/6047NGveB   Can't make it? Check back for additional events throughout the summer.  #WeAreFord #NowHiring #BOBPM
From the screen to the track. Frankie Muniz sat down with Jim to talk about his new life as a professional racer on the latest episode of DRIVE.

The chilly weather didn’t stop Ford employee Ronald Gosciniak and other Mustang owners from dropping the top for Cars and Coffee at Ford’s World Headquarters recently. Gosciniak, who works in prototype parts management, brought his heavily modified Chrome Yellow 1998 Mustang Cobra convertible for the crowd of over 1,500 employees and members of the public to admire.  Over 300 people brought vehicles for display with Mustangs being the predominant vehicles, though Broncos, Thunderbirds, and other Ford-built classics were part of the event. There was also a selection of vehicles from the recently announced Ford Heritage Fleet, a curated collection of nearly 500 vehicles globally showcasing the company’s legacy.  Gosciniak enjoyed seeing the Ford GTs that were part of the display – he worked on the HVAC vents for the prototype program. He said Ford can use learnings from vehicles in the fleet to help track customer trends.  “It’s super cool to see so many folks of all kinds of different ages coming out, showcasing our products, and it’s super cool to see new and old coming together,” said Jeff Waraniak, a strategic communications employee. “Ford does a great job of embracing the car community.”  Ford Heritage and Brand Manager Ted Ryan also saw the event as a way to get more employees and the public to engage with the Heritage Fleet.  “The thing I’ve loved is inside the garage where people are seeing the concepts,” he said. “Just everybody's stopping and taking pictures. That's why we do this – we’re car people.”  Do you believe cars can bring people together? Join us at http://spr.ly/6043NGSjb   #WeAreFord #EmployeeExperience

It’s satisfying to see Ford vehicles on the road every day, but when you work for a heritage brand like Ford it’s also fun to see the blue oval displayed on people’s clothes, bags, cups, hats and more everywhere you go. Recent Global Brand Merchandising and Licensing hire Jacqueline F. is part of the team that makes it easy to find and purchase fresh new Ford merchandise online: http://spr.ly/6049N8OPl  The assistant e-commerce marketing specialist is excited to give customers the best experience possible when they browse for items designed for the Ford fandom. “I chose to join Ford because it has a wealth of opportunities for professional growth and development, and it’s a company that leads with innovation,” says Jacqueline. “For example, I had always wanted to learn how to code html and CSS and Ford has already given me access to classes to acquire that skill.”  If Jacqueline looks familiar to you, it may be because you’ve seen her before -- she acts and models in commercials in her spare time! As if that’s not enough, the recent MBA grad runs about 25 miles weekly and has completed 27 5K races. Her proudest running achievement so far is having her name engraved in a metro park walkway for a first-place win. She’s says she’s grateful that Ford’s commitment to work-life balance helps her pursue her interests outside of work.  Welcome, Jacqueline!  Would you like to work for a company that supports your growth both at work and beyond? Learn more about current opportunities at http://spr.ly/6040N8OPm.   #WeAreFord #NewHireSpotlight

I can’t wait to apply the skills and knowledge I learned in school to real-world situations,” says Mariam Elahdan, who is interning with the EV Strategy Vehicle Planning team.  Follow our FordCareers social channels to keep up with intern activities all summer.

Did you know Ford employees contributed more than 83,000 volunteer hours to community projects last year? We’re proud to share stories like this and much more in Ford Philanthropy’s 2024 Impact Report.  From ensuring access to nutritious food and essential transportation to supporting disaster relief efforts, we're committed to making a difference in the lives of over 5 million people in 39 countries.  Thank you to our employees, partners and the communities we serve. We’re building a better world, together. Learn more about our impact and how we’re moving communities forward in the full report below.  #FordPhilanthropy #SocialImpact #Volunteerism #Philanthropy #MakingADifference #WeAreFord

“It was just something that we came up with in the basement of the Product Development Center,” says Stephanie Simon, former intern and current Ford marketing manager for battery electric vehicles. And now, “this is people's full-time job. They built a facility!”  In 2018, Simon and her fellow intern Travis Bouchard, now a manager of future EV product marketing at Ford, came up with the concept for the Bronco OffRoadeo to highlight the relaunched Ford Bronco SUV brand. The immersive driving experience for Bronco fans has been so successful it was named Newsweek’s 2025 Marketing Disruptor of the Year.  As our first group of 2025 summer interns arrive this month, we wish them luck as they tackle new projects and have the opportunity to be drivers of change, just like Stephanie and Travis. Welcome!   Keep up with the latest in Ford internships and professional opportunities at careers.ford.com.  #WeAreFord #DriversOfChange #FordIntern #BroncoOffRoadeo

“We talk a lot about what Daddy does at work and she knows I fix the pipes, but it’s really cool to be able to show her different things and to get her to understand Ford is such a big company and how much we do beyond just building cars,” says Matt Huddleston, a Skilled Trades plumber.  Matt’s five-year-old daughter Evelin was one of more than 3,500 children who joined their parents at various buildings on Ford’s Dearborn, Michigan campus for Bring Your Child to Work Day.   From virtual reality to clay modeling to toasting pastries using the power from an all-electric Ford F-150 Lightning pickup, kids participated in a range of engaging hands-on experiences related to automotive jobs.  Would you like to work for a company your kids get excited about? Find out more about current opportunities at careers.ford.com  #WeAreFord #BringYourChildToWorkDay
Listen to Jim's latest podcast featuring renowned historian, filmmaker, Harvard professor, and host of the hit PBS docuseries “Finding Your Roots", Dr. Henry Louis Gates Jr.

Jacob Slimak, a software and systems engineer, is beginning his career in the Ford College Graduate rotational program, and Scott is proud to have him carry on a three-generation family tradition. What is it like to work at Ford BlueOval Battery Park? Check out what Talent Acquisition manager Leslie Williams, MBA has to say:  "BOBPM is making a real difference in the community. It’s a chance to be part of something bigger than yourself, contributing to the revitalization of Marshall and the surrounding area. You will work on challenging and rewarding projects, be part of a dedicated team, and have the opportunity to develop valuable skills. It’s also a great opportunity to make a lasting positive impact on a community."  Learn more about us and explore open roles by visiting our careers page today: http://spr.ly/60452yuEZ  #WeAreFord #NowHiring #Community #JoinOurTeam #BlueOvalBatteryPark #BOBPM #MarshallMichigan

“Even after being here a few months, I’m still pleasantly surprised at how much the people here care about me, not just the work I do,” says Alexander Sorensen, a recent Product Development hire. He said that what caught his attention during the interview process was Ford’s commitment to family. His first impression was quickly proven correct.  “We had our fifth child soon after I started at Ford. I was shocked with how much paternity leave was provided so soon after my hire. Not only that, but I was worried about backlash since I was still new to the position, but my people leader and supervisors were thrilled for me. They insisted that I take the time my family needed to adjust to our new baby.”  As a high-voltage build & test engineer for electric vehicles, Alexander says his work is both challenging and engaging, which helps him feel like he’s “truly making a difference.”  The engineer and dad will soon be able to add “published author” to his resume. While working on papers for technical journals, he discovered how much he enjoyed the writing process, so the lifelong science fiction and fantasy reader began to write for fun. His first fantasy and magical realism book will be coming out this fall.  Alexander knows coming to Ford was the right decision for his career and his family. “The culture here has been super welcoming and really has helped me to feel included and cared for. I love being able to work on cutting-edge and amazing technology and have the peace of mind that my family matters to Ford.”   Welcome, Alexander!  Looking for a company that helps you grow your career and your family at the same time? Learn more at http://spr.ly/60462D8Sk.   #WeAreFord #NewHireSpotlight

Ford Design’s Daniel Kangas’ ten-year Fordiversary coincides with the debut of the latest project he worked on, the Ford Bronco Sport Sasquatch edition SUV. The senior exterior designer says, “I feel confident that I have the best job in the world. So much of that is due to the endlessly talented creatives and mentors around me. It’s been a fantastic 10 years so far!”  Dan grew up in southeast Wisconsin and says he had “no connections to the auto industry” but he always loved everything about cars, especially drawing them. He found Lawrence Technological University’s Transportation Design program, where he fell in love with the Motor City, interned at Ford, and joined the company after graduation.  He says he’s been lucky to have worked on a wide range of production and prototype projects – passenger vehicles, Ford Performance, graphics projects, concept builds and show vehicles. The highlight, though? “That has to be the Bronco R race prototype from 2021. Not only did we have only three months to design and build the vehicle from scratch to compete in the Baja 1000, but it would also be the first glimpse the world would see of the brand-new Ford Bronco that we had cooking. The team talent and collaboration made it one of those once-in-a-career experiences that I’ll never forget.”  Dan loves being part of Team Bronco, but he’s particularly passionate about the Bronco Sport. “I’d argue that ripping around in the Bronco Sport Sasquatch is the some of the most fun you can have in a Bronco, period.”  Find out more about the design behind the Ford Bronco Sport Sasquatch edition with Dan and his Ford Design colleague, color and material design manager Kellie Walters.   Want to get your Ford Design career started? Find current opportunities at http://spr.ly/60412L7VU  #WeAreFord #FordDesign

Since 1949, Ford Philanthropy has proudly supported the American Red Cross through disaster relief, employee blood drives, and countless other initiatives. Today, on Red Cross Giving Day, they are honoring this longstanding partnership by matching donations up to $250,000 until midnight ET! The Red Cross's work is more critical than ever, helping us build stronger communities together and respond to crises across the US. Donate now and double your impact. ‌ But giving doesn't stop there. You can also get involved by donating blood, volunteering, or learning lifesaving skills. Together, we can continue turning compassion into action, just as we've done for generations.

From Michigan Proving Grounds to rallycross courses around the country, the Mustang Mach-E Rally SUV has proven itself a true contender. The early reviews are in, and they’re saying Ford’s first-ever rally-inspired electric vehicle delivers on the hype.  “I just turned on my racer brain and gave it my all and the car didn’t hold me back. It gave me a big sense of pride to come out on top and it validated everything the team has done,” says Anthony Magagnoli, off-road development engineer and Mustang Mach-E Rally development driver. Magagnoli, along with other Ford employees, have found that the vehicle is far beyond a “sticker and tire package” on the course.  Would you like to be part of a team that loves vehicles as much as you do? Learn more about current opportunities at careers.ford.com   #WeAreFord
Thanks for introducing us to the newest group of BlueOval Battery Park Michigan team members, Scott! Welcome!   Learn more about BOBPM and join the team: https://lnkd.in/dXxDffv6  #WeAreFord #BOBPM

For Kyle Tretow, being hired by Ford Performance was a childhood dream come true. The motorsports powertrain design engineer comes from a long line of auto mechanics who owned a family auto repair shop and his dad and uncles worked in professional auto racing.  “I’ve been obsessed with fast cars and competition from a young age,” Kyle says. “It wasn’t until my undergrad years of college in mechanical engineering, when I joined University of North Carolina-Charlotte’s Formula SAE team, that I really began to discover my love of designing components from a clean sheet.”  He interfaced with his Ford Performance co-workers and supervisor as part of his previous job and that gave him some insight into the culture, but he says it’s been even better than expected. “The close-knit team and collaboration of everyone within Ford Performance has been amazing. My first week, Mark Rushbrook and Patrick DiMarco shook my hand, asked if I was Kyle, and introduced themselves before I even had a chance to tell them who I was. That showed me how much they care about the people working here.”  Kyle is excited about the variety of projects he’ll be working on. He’ll be helping develop and evolve the engine platforms for things as varied as GT3 and LMDh road racing, 410 sprint cars for dirt ovals, Dakar Raptor T1+ and other Bronco and Ranger Raptor programs for off-road, and more. As a newlywed, he’s also excited about gaining benefits like family-building assistance and more vacation time for better work-life balance.  Welcome to the team, Kyle!  Ready to make your childhood racing dreams come true? Check out current opportunities at http://spr.ly/60400NQN2 .    #WeAreFord #FordPerformance #NewHireSpotlight

The team at Ford Ion Park is working on breakthrough battery technology with the ultimate goal of affordable electric vehicles for everyone. The new Lithium Manganese Rich (LMR) batteries offer:  ✅ Enhanced safety and stability ✅ Lower cost ✅ Industry-leading energy density that results in longer range  This technology is key in offering electric vehicles that are both accessible and desirable.

Connor has done just that, and recently published his first children’s book, The Lonely Dragon. Congratulations, Connor! Welcome back to another season of DRIVE with Jim Farley!   In the first episode, Jim and Rob Gronkowski share a lively conversation, ranging from growing up with four brothers, his college antics, and even his custom Ford Bronco (a.k.a. “The Gronko”). Gronk also shares his perspectives on financial wisdom, leadership, and embracing his post-football career.

When we asked Candice Pritchett what made her choose Ford, there was no hesitation. “The people! From my first experience with my recruiter to meeting my hiring manager and leadership, it was clear to me that the culture at Ford was positive, motivational and transparent.”  Candice recently joined Ford Pro as a digital experience specialist, which means she’s managing the way North American customers interact with the Ford Pro website. She’ll be collaborating across organizations to ensure customers can find everything they need and more on the site, like vehicle launches, software, charging, service, and product financing.  She calls her career transition a “big leap” from the digital marketing and customer experience side of the real estate industry to the automotive industry but says she’s excited by the opportunities to learn and grow. “It’s fascinating to see how much research, development, and collaboration time goes into producing our vehicles. I’m not what you’d call a ‘car girl’ but after just a few months, I’m learning the lingo and starting to feel like a true pro!”  The emphasis on work-life balance and flexibility was also “a real plus” for Candice, as she and her high-school-sweetheart-turned-partner DeMarcus are new parents to six-month-old Aubrey. She says she also likes that paid volunteer hours allow her to make a difference and contribute to the community as part of her job.  “The team at Ford couldn’t have made the transition easier or more seamless. The people here are beyond brilliant and I'm so happy to be working alongside them.”   Welcome, Candice!  Looking to apply your expertise to a new industry like Candice? Learn more about current opportunities at http://spr.ly/6046LglRn.    #WeAreFord #NewHireSpotlight

“I love how welcoming everyone is and how helpful my team was when I first joined the company,” says engineer Morgan Wright. “Ford does a great job at giving you the tools you need to succeed and surrounds you with people to help you accomplish your goals.”  She recently began her Ford career as part of the Ford College Graduate developmental program, which will allow her to work in several areas of Product Development during her first few years here.  Morgan was an active member of the Georgia Institute of Technology chapter of NSBE as a student and plans to join the professional chapter in Detroit. She’s excited to attend the NSBE convention as a recruiter this year and can’t wait to meet everyone.   Stop by the booth to meet Morgan and the rest of the Ford team in Chicago to learn more about her transition from student to automotive engineer! March 5-9 at McCormick Place. Why do we employ the most hourly autoworkers in the country? Why do we assemble the most vehicles in the country? Because we’re committed to doing what’s right for the country.   Ford Motor Company. From America, for America.

“I’ve seen firsthand Ford’s commitment to innovation. Working here is more than just a job. It’s a legacy,” says Luree Brown, experience strategy lead at Ford and longtime member of the National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE).  Ten years ago, Luree started in Manufacturing launching new vehicles and then moved to Customer Experience. She’s the fourth generation of her family to work at Ford, and says, “It’s a place where you can build a lasting career, contribute to iconic vehicles, and create memorable customer experiences.”  She’s been part of NSBE even longer than she’s been part of Ford: her first NSBE national conference was in 2008 and for the last five years, she’s been on the other side of the booth as a recruiter. “Whether you’re a potential candidate interested in joining our team or a future customer that’s interested in our new lineup, I can’t wait to connect in Chicago,” Luree says.  Luree and the Ford team will be at booth 2244 in Chicago from March 5-9. Stop by and find out how you can move the world and make the future with us! #WeAreFord #NSBE
See you in Chicago! 🚘🎉     #WeAreFord #NSBE

“I have always loved the company and the people here, so when I was ready to return to the workforce, it was a given that I’d consider Ford,” says Emily Ferrara, integrated marketing manager for Ford Pass and Lincoln Way.  After relocating to another state and having children, she is thrilled to be back “engaging with former colleagues, using my expertise and working remotely, which provides a great work-life balance. My team is full of incredibly smart people to learn from, too.”  Emily is part of the Integrated Services team’s efforts to share all the great benefits customers can gain by downloading the Ford Pass and Lincoln Way apps. “I've been able to jump back in and apply my Ford-based knowledge, while learning something new and fresh about apps and the technology we offer. I’m also encouraged to see the use of AI and new ways of working that didn’t exist during my last tenure here. It's been fun, new and familiar at the same time!”  Emily calls herself “a Ford girl through and through”—her grandfather worked for Ford and her husband’s parents met on the assembly line in Wixom. “Our family was quite literally created from the blue oval in a sense, and I’m honored that I can add my chapter to our Ford story.”  As any parent knows, spare time is rare, but she has managed to pick up a hobby recently. As a new DIY enthusiast, she has accumulated a collection of power tools, saws and other equipment and is busy transforming her family’s home into their dream space (check out her handiwork in the pictures.) Next project: finishing the basement!  Whether you’re re-entering the workforce or looking for a new challenge, you can start your next chapter at Ford. Learn more at http://spr.ly/6044xWxYC   #WeAreFord #NewHireSpotlight

Senior data engineer Vijetha Senigaram has been been recognized by a national organization for her work in making the critical data that Ford uses in Manufacturing and Supply Chain analytics accessible and easier to use. Not only that, the solution mitigates potential losses, increases efficiency and saves money for the company.  Senigaram, part of the Data Platform and Engineering team in Global Data Insights and Analytics, was recently honored with a Patent Recognition Award by the Society of Women Engineers for this work.  Senigaram’s innovative solution framework, which dates back to 2018, resolves the longstanding issue of data being rendered unusable in some analytics programs. She was granted a patent for her framework in 2023, and one of the projects supported by her solution earned a Henry Ford Technology Award, the company’s highest technical honor, in 2021. Congratulations, Vijetha!  Would you like to work with innovative technical experts like Vijetha? Learn more at http://spr.ly/6045QFw0l  #WeAreFord #SWE

Our hearts go out to those impacted by the devastating fires in Southern California. Ford has always shown up for communities, and we are committed to being there for the Los Angeles area now and over the long journey ahead.   Today we announced two grants to support urgent critical relief needs, one to the Los Angeles Fire Department Foundation and one to the California Community Foundation's Wildfire Recovery Fund.   These contributions are on top of Ford Philanthropy’s long-term, ongoing support for the American Red Cross, Feeding America and Team Rubicon, organizations that are already providing shelter, food, and other on-the-ground support.   We know that there is more we can and will do, but right now our focus is on helping to address immediate critical needs. That includes ensuring that firefighters, first responders and others risking their lives are cared for and supported.  Please join us and our employees in supporting these efforts by contributing to: Team Rubicon: https://lnkd.in/dEbQ9aZZ California Community Foundation: https://lnkd.in/gPY-uGU3 American Red Cross: https://lnkd.in/dEbQ9aZZ Feeding America: https://lnkd.in/ekmewMge

Scott Morton, a senior operations manager for Integrated Services, was drawn back to Michigan from Wisconsin in 2013. When he joined Ford he had no idea that one day he’d be working at the newly remodeled Michigan Central Station, a historical building with family ties. His wife’s grandfather worked at the train station for the railroad company doing pre-computer era analysis, tracking data for the company. Morton also recently learned that as a child his mother traveled through the station to San Francisco to meet up with her father, who had been deployed to Japan with the Army in the 1950s.  He has also forged another connection on his own. In 2023, Morton created a nonprofit, Elevate, aimed at bringing stability and flexibility of transportation to Detroiters. Created at The Factory, Ford’s office space just down the road from Michigan Central in Corktown, the organization offers older model Ford vehicles on an all-inclusive subscription basis. Elevate was acquired by another nonprofit organization, Feonix – Mobility Rising, which operates out of the Book Depository building in the Michigan Central complex.  Morton says Ford went above and beyond in its redevelopment project, and believes the refurbished building, its location, and the collaborative nature of Michigan Central may help Ford attract new talent at a time when the city is being shaped into a tech and innovation hub. “The fact that we're open and embracing new ideas, new people, and new entrepreneurs who can challenge us, I think that's only going to make us stronger.”  Morton has felt a kinship with native Detroiters since returning to the area and feels privileged to be working there. He also looks forward to area amenities, such as the RiverWalk. “To see Michigan Central Station and the whole Corktown community makes me really proud of Michigan, the city, and Ford. It’s really cool to be able to work there.”  Would you like to work at a company that values the best of the past and uses it to transform the future? Join us at http://spr.ly/6046SxF5n #WeAreFord

Brian Rockwell, a strategy lead for Ford’s Integrated Services, saw the renovated Michigan Central Station for the first time recently when his team moved in, but he has been connected to it for over a century. His great-grandfather worked in the ticket office when the train station opened in 1913, and was employed there until he departed for World War I with his brother Milo in 1917.  “Having not even grown up in Michigan, what are the odds? My great-grandfather worked in the building when it opened over 100 years ago, and I’m working there as it reopens. It makes you wonder about fate or a plan for the universe,” said Rockwell, who now resides in Northville, Michigan.  Beyond his family ties to the building, Brian said being located at Michigan Central is going to be great for Integrated Services, which is driving innovation for the company and will be able to take advantage of the collaborative environment there.  “Everybody's really excited about it for a lot of different reasons,” he said. “There's a lot of excitement about the building itself and its history, but also about being in Corktown, which is such a lively area,” noting the nearby Ford office locations and restaurants.  Rockwell also said he thinks of Integrated Services’ move from Ford’s World Headquarters to Michigan Central symbolizes the transformation taking place at Ford and within the automotive industry and helps solidify the team as an innovation hub for the company. Although he’s not a native Detroiter, Rockwell has always had a soft spot for the automotive business. “The things that we do here have a huge impact on people's lives,” he said.  We’re bringing the best parts of the past along with us as we make the future. Want to join us? Visit http://spr.ly/6047qC8MS.   #WeAreFord #MichiganCentralStation

The remodeled Michigan Central Station is so much more than just a pretty space – it’s also a vibrant work environment, among other things.  Bill Ford’s vision for Michigan Central was informed by an understanding that the intersection of different ideas and perspectives drive innovation, and success in the industry requires an open platform where companies and sectors collaborate – even competitors.  Michigan Central will bring Ford employees from Model e and Integrated Services together with Ford Pro and others – and when needed, external partners, entrepreneurs, students, and community members – to co-create new products, services, and technologies that add value to a new generation of Ford customers and help build a better world. While Ford’s investment is crucial to the company’s long-term planning, it also represents a commitment to the city of Detroit and its future, becoming a beacon of development and opportunity.  Love the idea of innovative workspaces? Learn more about how you can work in one at http://spr.ly/6046qCBqY. #WeAreFord

As part of Global Caring Month, Ford Thailand, in partnership with Sati Foundation, launched the Give to Grow program. The program provided essential infrastructure, technology systems, area improvement, and life skill workshops, each tailored to the specific needs of three schools in Chonburi and Rayong provinces. Over 150 volunteers, including Ford employees from Bangkok, Ford Thailand Manufacturing (FTM), AutoAlliance Thailand (AAT), Ford Ek Group dealership and private sector partners, helped make a positive impact.  In collaboration with partners like WHA Corporation Public Company Limited, Prime Power Company Limited, and R 1-2 Thai Engineering Company Limited, the volunteers joined in delivering equipment, installing a 5-kiowatt solar roof system, water filtration systems, rebuilding playgrounds, installing restrooms and fences and other projects.  Thanks to the hard-working volunteers who made these schools safe, energy-efficient and beautiful places to learn!  If you believe in giving back to the community you work in, learn more at http://spr.ly/6042qN9QY   #WeAreFord #FordThailand #FordIMG
